column4: Hi all is there a way to control via Ubuntu the function of the Wifi on/off "soft-button" on the laptop?
on laptops with proper kernel support they *should* do the right thing out of the box
I haven't looked into how much hassle it is to remap them to something else.
Unfortunatelly hp laptops have a (hardware) faulty wifi button which means if it fails you're left with no connection

there's a bunch of documentation on this in the kernel docs tree (the magic word is "rfkill"). Some of them are actually hardwired at the hardware level, so the kernel can't really fix those if they break.
That's what I feared.
define "a nasty error"
soreau: Ok. http://paste.ubuntu.com/222195/
soreau: Notice this happens any time I do some apt-get stuff
is it correct about /usr/sbin/update-grub not existing?
yes
afaik the "grub" package is supposed to own that script, is that intentionally not installed?
No.. The only "hackish" thing I did was to modify the menu.lst file
I don't know where that script went, but consider reinstalling the "grub" package
How can I "reinstall" it?
not sure, but it's probably something like "apt-get install grub --reinstall"
weird that you don't just have that script already though. It shouldn't just vanish, and iiuc it's just owned by jaunty's grub package here.
Turns out grub was not officially "installed" ????
weird, I had it installed after a straightforward jaunty install.
situation might be different in karmic though, which use grub 2, iirc.
Now I'm going through the install I remember it was installed during upgrades, I updated to 9.04 recently
(re)Installing grub seems to solve the problem.
thanks.
